title: Lebanese people in the United Kingdom
text:
Lebanese people in the United Kingdom include people originating from <a href="Lebanon">Lebanon</a> who have migrated to the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> and their descendants.
History and settlement.
Although there has been sporadic migration from the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a> to Britain since the 17th century, the real growth of the UK Lebanese population began in 1975, with the start of the <a href="Lebanese%20Civil%20War">civil war</a> in Lebanon which drove thousands of people away. The exodus was aggravated in 1982 with the <a href="1982%20Lebanon%20War">Israeli invasion</a>. At the same time, many Lebanese expatriates who were based in <a href="West%20Africa">West Africa</a>, in particular <a href="Nigeria">Nigeria</a>, left for Britain as subsequent military governments took control in those areas.
Demographics.
The <a href="2001%20UK%20Census">2001 UK Census</a> recorded 10,459 Lebanese-born people. The 2011 census recorded 15,341 people born in Lebanon residing in England, 228 in Wales, 314 in Scotland and 52 in Northern Ireland.
<a href="Edgware%20Road">Edgware Road</a> in London is one of a number of areas that the Lebanese community has settled in and has shops selling Arabic newspapers, books and music. Other areas with Lebanese communities in London include <a href="Bayswater">Bayswater</a>, <a href="Kensington">Kensington</a> and <a href="Westbourne%20Grove">Westbourne Grove</a>.
